title: What evidence suggests the existence of pagan initiation centers in ancient Rome, and how did initiates respond to the dominance of Christianity?
first_phrase: In the previous text, the author talks about the deep-seated hatred of the dominant religion in the West towards paganism. Even Christian denominations accuse each other of having pagan influences. This antipagan obsession reveals the virulent animosity that still exists towards paganism, making it difficult for pagan initiatic centers to thrive. In the last 200 tokens, the author notes that the existence and work of Apollonio, Plotino, Massimo, and Giuliano in the last centuries of the pagan world serve as evidence of the presence of pagan initiatic centers during the Roman Empire.
content: Perciò, quando anche il silenzio fosse rimasto assoluto, potrebbe darsi che si trattasse di silenzio ermetico o pitagorico, e non risulterebbe provato trattarsi necessariamente o verosi milmente di un silenzio di tomba. Constatiamo intanto che, prima della vittoria del Galileo, negli ultimi gloriosi secoli del mondo pagano l'esistenza e l'opera di Apollonio, Plotino, Massimo, Giuliano, è un indizio abbastanza probante della esi stenza ai tempi di Roma imperiale di centri iniziatici pagani.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the existence of pagan initiatory centers during the Imperial Roman period is a significant indicator of the attempts to keep alive the pagan religion. The initiates, after unsuccessful efforts to revive their religion and the violent destruction of their sanctuaries, may have chosen to either become more secretive or to conceal themselves under a Christian guise. Their priority was to ensure the continuity of their sacred knowledge and to maintain the purity and completeness of their tradition, even if done in secrecy.
